thread.title: LU's offensive linemen have exceeded expectations
thread.title_full: LU's offensive linemen have exceeded expectations

author: Danny Shapiro
title: LU's offensive linemen have exceeded expectations
text:
Close Image 1 of 1 Lamar University's offensive linemen, including (from left) Matthew Oubre, Justin Brock, and Cody Elenz, have been in top form this season, giving up only one sack, and providing a strong support for the success of Kade Harrington. Photo taken Tuesday, October 13, 2015 Kim Brent/The Enterprise Lamar University's offensive linemen, including (from left) Matthew Oubre, Justin Brock, and Cody Elenz, have been in top form this season, giving up only one sack, and providing a strong support for the ... more Photo: Kim Brent LU's offensive linemen have exceeded expectations 1 / 1 Back to Gallery 
The Lamar Cardinals' offensive linemen have earned their fishing trips to Sabine Lake thus far. 
The Cardinal linemen have allowed only one sack through five games and have consistently opened holes for the Southland Conference's leading rusher in junior running back Kade Harrington . 
Offensive coordinator Chuck Langston has been more than happy with the way offensive line has performed in the trenches. 
"I can't brag enough about (the offensive line)," Langston said. "They're a great group of guys. They seem to do everything together, even fish." 
It's on those fishing trips that the Cardinals' offensive line started becoming close and earning Langston's approval. 
The Cardinals had to replace three starters along the front line including at center, where sophomore Matthew Oubre , a transfer from Louisiana-Monroe, has filled in admirably. 
Oubre arrived in the spring, when the fishing trips and group camaraderie began. 
"We just started doing everything as a group," Oubre said. "We fish together a lot and if one of us is hungry, we all go eat. We're just really close." 
Oubre wasn't the only transfer that had to get acclimated to a new school, teammates and scheme. But so did junior starting left tackle Cody Elenz , a University of Idaho transfer. 
Elenz wasn't expecting the group to gel as quickly as it has, but said the fishing trips, along with the fact they live in the same apartment complex, has been key to their success. 
"I didn't think we'd come together this quickly," Elenz said. "But this is the most cohesion I've seen in a group since high school." 
Lone returning starters Justin Brock and Bret Treadway were admittedly nervous about the Cardinals having to replace three starters. But the performances of Oubre, Elenz and junior Dante Cattaneo have eased those concerns. 
"It wasn't difficult at all for us all to gel," Brock said. "A lot of the new guys ended up having a lot of experience and it all helped out." 
Brock believes the offensive line won't peak until the end of the season, but their best game thus far was last week against Abilene Christian , when Harrington ran for a conference-record 347 yards. 
"We've had the same five guys in there all season," Langston said. "That's a big key to why we've been able to be so successful. 
"They're all just best friends," Langston continued. "It's like they've been together forever. I'm proud of what they've done so far."
